statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description:
Latrell Sprewell and the New York Knicks 
taught the Cleveland Cavaliers a lesson in unselfish basketball.
article.headline: Knicks blow out Cavaliers by 32 points
article.linkText: Lowly Cavs fall to Knicks for 15th straight loss
article.story:
NEW YORK (AP) -- Asked to recall the last time the Knicks had such an easy time, Latrell Sprewell drew a blank.
Houston

''I can't even remember,'' Sprewell said. ''I can't even tell you when we had a big game like that.'' Sprewell's memory lapse was understandable Monday night following New York's 125-93 victory over Cleveland -- the Cavaliers' 15th consecutive loss. Not since April 14, when the Knicks beat Miami by 27 points for their 30th and final victory of last season, had they enjoyed such an easy win. Allan Houston scored 29 points and Kurt Thomas had a career-high six blocks to go with 22 points for the Knicks, who have put together their first three-game winning streak since January. The Knicks surpassed the 100-point plateau for just the second time this season in a game that wasn't close for the final three quarters. ''We're still going to have problems because of our size, but the team's starting to realize if we're going to win games then we're going to have to play a certain way,'' coach Don Chaney said. Sprewell added 11 assists and Howard Eisley had 10 for the Knicks, who shot 53 percent, led by Thomas' 11-for-15 effort. Dajuan Wagner had 25 points and 10 assists for the Cavs, who are closing in on the longest losing streak in franchise history -- 19 games during the 1981-82 season. The 32-point margin of defeat matched their second-largest of the season. Cleveland was without three key players, Ricky Davis (team suspension), Tyrone Hill (sprained ankle) and Darius Miles (knee tendinitis), and only managed to keep the game competitive for a few minutes. ''We're just really young. It's no fun,'' Cleveland coach John Lucas said. ''were not close without all our players.'' Things started to go south for the Cavs as soon as backup center Michael Stewart entered the game midway through the first quarter with Cleveland leading 14-12. The Knicks went on a 14-2 run, ending with an 11-foot runner by Houston for a 26-16 lead. New York had a 9-0 run to start the second quarter and an 8-0 run later in the period, taking a 26-point lead on two free throws by Clarence Weatherspoon with 5:42 left that made it 52-26. Thomas had all of his blocks by halftime, and the Knicks had a 29-14 edge in rebounding at intermission. ''I've had 12 blocks before. I've had triple-doubles,'' Thomas said, referring to his collegiate days at TCU. Houston gave New York its first 30-point lead on a 3-pointer just 1:12 into the third quarter, then hit three more 3s over the remainder of the period to help the Knicks take a 99-71 lead into the fourth. Houston left for good with 9:16 left and the Knicks leading 108-75. Before the game, Knicks president Scott Layden said the team was unlikely to use the $4.5 million medical exception it received for the season-ending knee injury to Antonio McDyess. The exception was due to expire at midnight. ''We looked at all the possibilities and didn't see anything out there that would significantly improve the team,'' Layden said. That means the personnel on the league's worst rebounding and shot-blocking team will remain the same for the time being -- although those areas weren't a problem against the Cavs. New York had a 53-31 edge on the boards to go with eight blocks. Game notes
Knicks G Charlie Ward returned from a nine-game absence (bruised leg) and had two points on 1-for-6 shooting with four assists in 17 minutes. ... Cleveland centers Carlos Boozer (18 points, seven rebounds) and DeSagana Diop (four points, three rebounds) both fouled out. ... Davis, suspended for an on-court argument with Hill, will be back in the lineup Wednesday night against Washington. ... The Knicks activated swingman Lavor Postell, two months after he underwent arthroscopic knee surgery. He scored five points in eight minutes. ... Cleveland dropped to 0-5 vs sub-.500 teams and 0-8 when allowing 100 or more points.
